contextId.occurrenceNote: In the Bible, people are often spoken of as trees. People who delight in Yahweh's law can do all God wants them to do just as a tree that is planted by water produces good fruit. Alternate translation: "He will be prosperous like a tree ... fruit in its season" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He will be like a tree ... fruit in its season

contextId.occurrenceNote: How they are like chaff can be stated clearly. Alternate translation: "but instead they are worthless like the chaff" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: but are instead like the chaff

contextId.occurrenceNote: God's favor is spoken of as if it were a shield. Alternate translation: "you will favor them and protect them as a soldier protects himself with his shield" or "because you are kind to them, you will protect them (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: you will surround them with favor as with a shield

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of his enemies attacking him as if they would rip his body apart and tear it in pieces as a lion would. Alternate translation: "they will violently kill me like a lion ripping apart its victim's body and tearing it in pieces" or "they will violently kill me" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they will rip me apart like a lion, tearing me in pieces

contextId.occurrenceNote: The enemy is spoken of as if it were a city full of broken down buildings. Alternate translation: "Our enemies were destroyed" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The enemy crumbled like ruins

contextId.occurrenceNote: This speaks of the wicked person as if he were a lion. Alternate translation: "He hides while he waits for the weak to walk near him, the same way a lion quietly waits in the bush for the animal it wants to attack" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He lurks in secret like a lion in the thicket

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's words are compared to silver that has been purified. Alternate translation: "they are without any imperfection" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like silver purified in a furnace on the earth, refined seven times

contextId.occurrenceNote: The "apple of your eye" refers to something that is valuable. Alternate translation: "Protect me as you would something most valuable and precious" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Protect me like the apple of your eye

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer feels pursued the way a lion hunts its prey (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They are like a lion ... like a young lion

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's voice sounded like thunder. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh thundered in the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: God gives strength to David as if it were a piece of clothing. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: puts strength on me like a belt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The deer is especially quick and stable in the mountains. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a deer and places me on the heights

contextId.occurrenceNote: The Psalmist says that Yahweh has given him strength that surrounds and supports him like a belt. See how you translated this in [Psalms 18:32](../018/032.md). (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: put strength on me like a belt

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmists enemies are compared to dust to show how defeated they are. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I beat them into fine pieces like dust before the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist's enemies are compared to mud in the streets to show how defeated they are. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I threw them out like mud in the streets

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the sun's coming out as if it were a bridegroom. Alternate translation: "The sun is like a bridegroom walking joyfully toward his bride" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The sun is like a bridegroom coming out of his chamber

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares the sun to an athlete to emphasize the strength and brightness of the sun. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a strong man who rejoices when he runs his race

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about his enemies as if they were lions. This emphasizes how powerful and dangerous his enemies are. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a roaring lion ripping its victim

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about feeling completely exhausted and weak as if he were water being poured out of a jar. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I am being poured out like water

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about no longer having courage as if his heart melted like wax. Here "heart" represents "courage." (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: My heart is like wax ... inner parts

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about feeling weak as if his strength were like a dry piece of pottery that can easily break. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: My strength has dried up like a piece of pottery

contextId.occurrenceNote: The ground of Lebanon shaking is spoken of as if it were a young calf skipping. This emphasizes that when Yahweh speaks, the power of his voice shakes the ground. Alternate translation: "He makes the land of Lebanon shake like a calf skipping" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He makes Lebanon skip like a calf

contextId.occurrenceNote: People do not think about dead people. The writer does not think people think about him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as a dead man whom no one thinks about

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of himself as if he was completely useless. "as useless as a broken pot" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a broken pot

contextId.occurrenceNote: David's strength is compared to a small, green plant that turns brown and crumbles in the dry season. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: My strength withered as in summer drought

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares people with no understanding to horses and mules. Possible meanings are 1) the writer is speaking Yahweh's words to his readers, "You all must not be like a horse ... no understanding" or 2) Yahweh is speaking to the writer as though to a group of people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Do not be like a horse ... no understanding

contextId.occurrenceNote: "like behind a dam." The writer describes the creation of the sea as if God piles up all the waters together. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a heap

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer's enemies are spoken of as if they are chaff that is easily blown away. Alternate translation: "blown away by the wind like chaff" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as chaff before the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer was as sad as if his own brother had died. Alternate translation: "grieving as if my own brother was ill" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: in grief as for my brother

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer mourned as if his own mother had died. Alternate translation: "I mourned as if my own mother had died" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I bent down in mourning as for my mother

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases describe the greatness of God's righteousness and judgments as if they were very high and deep. Alternate translation: "as high as the highest mountains ... as deep as the deepest sea" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like the mountains of God ... like the great deep

contextId.occurrenceNote: Evildoers are spoken of as if they are grass and plants that dry up and die in the hot weather. These two similes both mean they will die. Alternate translation: "die" or "come to an end" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: dry up as the grass ... wither as the green plants

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means "in full view of everyone." Alternate translation: "as clear to see as the light of day" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like the daylight

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means "as visible as the noon sun." Alternate translation: "as visible as the light at the brightest time of day" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like the day at noon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares Yahweh's enemies to the flowers blooming in the fields. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Yahweh's enemies will be like the glory of the pastures

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the prosperity of the wicked man is spoken of as if he were a healthy tree growing in good soil. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: spread out like a green tree in its native soil

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer does not listen to what his enemies are saying. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I am like a deaf man ... hear nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer does not speak evil words to or about his enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I am like a mute man ... says nothing

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile states that the length of the writer's life is so short that it does not exist. This is an exaggeration to stress how short it is. Alternate translation: "the length of my life is barely any time at all" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-hyperbole]])
contextId.glQuote: my lifetime is like nothing before you

contextId.occurrenceNote: The lives of people are spoken of as if they are as insignificant as shadows. Alternate translation: "Everyone disappears like shadows do" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Surely every man walks about like a shadow

contextId.occurrenceNote: God will take away the things they value in the same way as a moth eats a piece of cloth. Alternate translation: "consume the things they desire like a moth eats away at clothing" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: consume the things they desire like a moth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of Yahweh's lack of response as if Yahweh considered him to be a total stranger to him. Alternate translation: "I am like a complete stranger to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I am like a foreigner with you, a refugee

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer describes his adversaries' rebukes as his receiving a fatal wound. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As with a sword in my bones

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares the Israelites to sheep that people kill and eat. As sheep are helpless before those who kill them, so the Israelites are helpless before their enemies. This can be translated in active form. Alternate translation: "You have allowed our enemies to kill us like they would kill a sheep and eat it" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-activepassive]])
contextId.glQuote: You have made us like sheep to be slaughtered

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares people who will all die to a flock of sheep. Just as sheep cannot escape when the butcher decides to slaughter them, so men will not escape when it is their time to die. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like sheep

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not having sin is spoken of as being white. Alternate translation: "very, very white" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: whiter than snow

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the tongue is compared to a sharp razor which is capable of causing great harm. Alternate translation: "Your tongue harms people like a sharp razor does, when you plan destruction and deceive others" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Your tongue plans destruction like a sharp razor, working deceitfully

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being safe and secure is spoken of as being like a strong tree. Alternate translation: "I am strong in God's house, like a green olive tree" or "Because I worship in God's house, I am secure like a green olive tree" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I am like a green olive tree in God's house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Speech that is pleasant or nice to hear is spoken of as if it were smooth and easy to swallow. Alternate translation: "What he said was pleasant like smooth butter" or "He said nice things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: His mouth was smooth as butter

contextId.occurrenceNote: People put oil on their skin to make it feel nice, and they put it on wounds to help them heal. Speech that is kind or helpful is spoken of as if it were soft or soothing. Alternate translation: "what he said was kind and soothing like oil" or "he said kind things" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: his words were softer than oil

contextId.occurrenceNote: Wicked people who do not listen to advice or rebukes are spoken of as if they were snakes that do not respond to a charmer's music. Alternate translation: "they refuse to listen like a deaf adder that stops up its ears" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they are like a deaf adder that stops up its ears

contextId.occurrenceNote: No longer existing is spoken of as melting and disappearing. Alternate translation: "Let the wicked vanish like a snail that melts and no longer exists" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Let them be like a snail that melts and passes away

contextId.occurrenceNote: Not existing is spoken of as being like a baby that is born dead. Alternate translation: "like a baby who is born too early too live and see the sunlight" or "like a baby that was born dead" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like the untimely-born child of a woman that never sees the sunlight

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of his enemies threatening to attack people as if they were dogs howling, growling, or barking at people. Alternate translation: "they threaten to attack people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they howl like dogs

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of his enemies threatening to attack people as if they were dogs howling, growling, or barking at people. Alternate translation: "threatening to attack us" or "threatening to attack us like wild dogs" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: howling like dogs

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the writer speaks of knowing and worshiping God as being more satisfying than eating a good meal. Alternate translation: "I will be happier than a person who eats a meal of fat and choice food" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: It will be as if I ate a meal of marrow and fatness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of his enemies' tongues as if they were as sharp as swords. Here "tongues" represents the harsh words that the enemies speak. Alternate translation: "The harsh things that they say hurt me like a sharp sword" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metonymy]])
contextId.glQuote: They have sharpened their tongues like swords

contextId.occurrenceNote: There were so many dead kings and soldiers on the mountain that they are spoken of as if they were snow covering the mountain. Alternate translation: "defeated so many enemy kings and soldiers there that they were like snowflakes covering Mount Zalmon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: scattered kings there ... snowed on Mount Zalmon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The king will be good, and he will do good things for his people as if he were rain doing good for freshly cut grass. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: May he come down like rain on the mown grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: "like the cedar trees in Lebanon." These trees were beautiful and had wood that was good for building. The meaning of this can be made clear. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: like Lebanon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The prosperity of the people in the cities is spoken of as if they were grass that grows abundantly in the fields. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: the people flourish in the cities like the grass of the field

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the wicked show everyone how proud and violent they are as if they were wearing a necklace or beautiful robe. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Pride adorns them like a necklace around their neck; violence clothes them like a robe

contextId.occurrenceNote: The wicked will last no longer than what a person sees in a dream. It disappears as soon as the person wakes up. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a dream after one wakes up

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile compares God's people to a flock of animals. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You led your people like a flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks about the Israelites as if they were sheep. This means God cared for and protected the people like a shepherd does his sheep. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like sheep ... like a flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings for this simile are 1) Yahweh has made his sanctuary as high as the heavens. Alternate translation: "He built his sanctuary high, like the heavens" or 2) Yahweh has made his sanctuary as permanent as the heavens. Alternate translation: "He built his sanctuary to last permanently, like the heavens last forever" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He built his sanctuary like the heavens

contextId.occurrenceNote: This simile compares the expression of God's anger to a fire that destroys things. Alternate translation: "destroy us" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-explicit]])
contextId.glQuote: burn like fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: This means the bodies of Sisera and Jabin were not buried but were left to rot. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: became like manure for the earth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer uses similes to describe God's total destruction of Israel's enemies. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: General Information:

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements speak of God destroying his enemies as if he were a strong wind easily blowing them away. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: make them like the whirling dust, like chaff before the wind

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements speak of God's punishment as if it were a fire, and the enemies of God are things that burn in the fire. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: like the fire that burns the forest, and like the flame that sets the mountains on fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: Both statements ask God to destroy the enemies with storms. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-parallelism]])
contextId.glQuote: Chase them with your strong wind, and terrify them with your windstorm

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer feeling like people and God have abandoned him speaks about himself as if he were already a dead person lying in a grave. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I am like the dead who lie in the grave

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares God's "angry actions" and "terrifying deeds" to a flood of water. Alternate translation: "All day long they threaten to destroy me like a flood" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They surround me like water all the day long

contextId.occurrenceNote: Someone from David's family always ruling as king is spoken of as if his his throne would last as long as the sky will last. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: his throne as enduring as the skies above

contextId.occurrenceNote: God compares David's rule as king to the sun to emphasize that someone from David's descendants will always rule as king. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: as long as the sun before me

contextId.occurrenceNote: God compares David's rule as king to the moon to emphasize that someone from David's descendants will always rule as king. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: forever like the moon

contextId.occurrenceNote: God being very angry is spoken of as if his anger were a hot fire. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: your anger burn like fire

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer means that a long period of time seems like a short period of time to God. Alternate translation: "You consider a thousand years the same as one day in the past, or as a few short hours in the night" or "Even a thousand years is not a long time to you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: For a thousand years in your sight are as yesterday when it is past, and as a watch in the night

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares human life to a sigh to emphasize that life is very brief. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a sigh

contextId.occurrenceNote: This compares evil people to grass, which grows quickly and in many places. Alternate translation: "When evil people appear quickly and seem to be everywhere, like grass" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: When the wicked sprout like the grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that righteous people will be like a healthy palm tree because they will 1) be strong or 2) live for long time. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The righteous will flourish like the palm tree

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that righteous people will be like a healthy cedar tree growing in the land of Lebanon because 1) they will be strong or 2) people will honor them. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they will grow like a cedar in Lebanon

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer speaks of the mountains crumbling before Yahweh as if they were wax that was exposed to a fire. Alternate translation: "The mountains are unable to stand as Yahweh comes near" or "The mountains crumble in Yahweh's presence" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The mountains melt like wax before Yahweh

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here "my days" refers to the author's life and the idea of "smoke" is something that quickly disappears. Alternate translation: "my life passes away quickly" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: my days pass away like smoke

contextId.occurrenceNote: This is another way to describe his despair. Alternate translation: "I feel like I am drying up like withered grass" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I am like grass that has withered

contextId.occurrenceNote: He compares his loneliness to that of a pelican, which is often seem alone instead of with other birds. Alternate translation: "I am lonely and despised like a pelican in the wilderness" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I am like a pelican of the wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: The author continues to describe loneliness by comparing himself to an owl in abandoned ruins. Alternate translation: "I have become alone like an owl in abandoned ruins" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I have become like an owl in the ruins

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares himself to a bird to emphasize his feeling of loneliness. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I lie awake like a solitary bird

contextId.occurrenceNote: David would have sat in ashes as an act of mourning, therefore ashes would have fallen on his food. Alternate translation: "I eat ashes like I eat bread" or "As I mourn, ashes fall on the bread that I eat" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I eat ashes like bread

contextId.occurrenceNote: David compares his time left to live on earth to a fading shadow. Alternate translation: "My time to remain alive is short like an evening shadow that will soon be gone" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: My days are like a shadow that fades

contextId.occurrenceNote: As David's body becomes weak and he is nearing the end of his life, he compares himself to withering grass. Alternate translation: "my body has become weak like withered grass" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I have withered like grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: Having your "youth renewed" means to feel young again. Here David compares this feeling of youth to the swiftness and strength of an eagle. Alternate translation: "you feel young and are strong like an eagle" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: your youth is renewed like the eagle

contextId.occurrenceNote: The simile compares the great distance between heaven and earth to the greatness of God's love for his people. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: For as the skies are high ... toward those who honor him

contextId.occurrenceNote: The distance between east and west is so far that it cannot be measured. In this simile, that distance is being compared to how far God moves our guilt away from us. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As far as the east ... removed the guilt of our sins from us

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the author compares a father's compassion for his children to Yahweh's compassion for those who honor him. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As a father has compassion ... on those who honor him

contextId.occurrenceNote: In this simile, the length of man's life is being compared to the short length of time that grass grows before it dies. Alternate translation: "The length of man's life is short like that of grass" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As for man, his days are like grass

contextId.occurrenceNote: In this simile, how man grows over time is compared to how a flower grows. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: he flourishes like a flower in a field

contextId.occurrenceNote: These phrases continue to talk about flowers and grass. They compare how flowers and grass die to how man dies. Alternate translation: "The wind blows over the flowers and grass and they disappear, and no one can tell where they once grewit is the same way with man" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: The wind blows over it, and it disappears ... where it once grew

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh is described as being covered with light as if the light were a garment around him. Alternate translation: "You are covered in light" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You cover yourself with light as with a garment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here God is described as spreading out the heavens like someone spreads out a tent when setting it up. Alternate translation: "you spread out the heavens like someone sets up a tent" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: you spread out the heavens like a tent curtain

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here the water that covered the earth is being compared to how a large garment is able to completely cover something. Alternate translation: "You completely covered the earth with water" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You covered the earth with water like a garment

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David compares the way that Yahweh led the Isrealites through the Sea of Reeds to the way people can be led across the dry ground of a wilderness. "The depths" refers the riverbed that appeared after Yahweh parted the waters. Alternate translation: "through the Seas of Reeds on dry ground" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: through the depths, as through a wilderness

contextId.occurrenceNote: Here David compares how Yahweh cares for his people to how a shepherd cares for his sheep. Possible meanings are 1) "makes the number of people in their families increase like flocks" or 2) "takes care of them like a shepherd cares for his sheep" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: cares for his families like a flock

contextId.occurrenceNote: People wore their clothes everyday. David speaks of a wicked person always being cursed as if his curses always covered him as his clothing does. Alternate translation: "Let his curses be on him every day like the garment he wears" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: May his curses be to him like the clothes he wears to cover himself

contextId.occurrenceNote: David speaks of them being ashamed as if it were a robe that they wore. Alternate translation: "may their shame cover them just like their robe is wrapped around them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: may they wear their shame like a robe

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares the enemy armies to a swarm of bees. Alternate translation: "They surrounded me like a swarm of bees would surround a person" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: They surrounded me like bees

contextId.occurrenceNote: Just like dry thorns burn out quickly, the attack of the enemy armies was quickly over. Alternate translation: "their attack lasted only a short time, as a fire that consumes thorns quickly dies" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: they disappeared as quickly as fire among thorns

contextId.occurrenceNote: A wineskin is ruined when it hangs for a long time in a smoke-filled place. The writer compares himself to a wineskin that has been ruined by smoke to emphasize that he feels useless. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I have become like a wineskin in the smoke

contextId.occurrenceNote: Slag is the waste or undesired leftovers in the process of refining gold or other metals. Yahweh removes the wicked people as if they were trash. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: You remove all the wicked of the earth like slag

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist compares his disobedience to Yahweh to a sheep that has wandered away from the flock. Alternate translation: "I have left your way like a sheep that has left its flock" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: I have wandered off like a lost sheep

contextId.occurrenceNote: People who trust in Yahweh are spoken of as if they they were Mount Zion. Mountains are unable to be moved. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Those who trust in Yahweh are like Mount Zion, unshakable, forever enduring

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh's protection is spoken of as if he was the mountains surrounding Jerusalem. Jerusalem was surrounded by several mountains, which protected it from attack. Alternate translation: "As the hills that surround Jerusalem protect it, so Yahweh protects his people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: As the mountains surround Jerusalem, so Yahweh surrounds his people

contextId.occurrenceNote: Arrows are very important to a warrior because they protect him in battle. Children are spoken of as if they are a warrior's arrow. Alternate translation: "Having many children will help to protect you" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Like arrows in the hand of a warrior, so are the children of one's youth

contextId.occurrenceNote: The wife is spoke of as a vine producing a lot of fruit. This implies that children are like fruit and the wife will have many children. Alternate translation: "very productive and give you many children" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a fruitful vine in your house

contextId.occurrenceNote: Children are compared to olive plants because of the way they grow to surround something. Children will surround the table and make it full. Alternate translation: "you will have many children who will grow and prosper" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: your children will be like olive plants

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of his enemies dying and being few in number. He compares them to the little bit of grass that grows on the roof of a house and withers and is not enough to cut or bundle. Alternate translation: "May they die and may there be few of them" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: May they be like the grass on the housetops that withers before it grows up

contextId.occurrenceNote: These words finish the simile that begins in ([Psalms 129:6](../129/006.md)). The psalmist speaks of his enemies dying and being few in number. He compares them to the little bit of grass that grows on the roof of a house and withers and is not enough to cut or bundle. "May they be like the grass, which cannot fill ... together" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: that cannot fill ... together

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist speaks of his desire for the Lord to help him as being greater than the desire that those who work all night have for the morning to come. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: My soul waits ... more than watchmen wait for the morning

contextId.occurrenceNote: The goodness of unity among God's people is spoken of as if it were like the fine oil that was poured on Aaron's head. Alternate translation: "This unity is precious like the oil that was poured on Aaron's head" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: It is like fine oil on the head

contextId.occurrenceNote: The goodness of unity among God's people is spoken of as it if it were refreshing like dew. Alternate translation: "refreshing like the dew of Hermon" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like the dew of Hermon

contextId.occurrenceNote: Being ignorant and powerless is spoken of as being like idols, which cannot speak, see, hear, or breathe. Alternate translation: "Those who make them are stupid and powerless like their idols" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: Those who make them are like them

contextId.occurrenceNote: The psalmist asks Yahweh to accept and be pleased with his prayer the way he would accept and be pleased with incense. Alternate translation: "May the my prayer please you the way the sweet smell of incense pleases people" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: May my prayer be like incense

contextId.occurrenceNote: The means to be like the animal that was burned on the altar in the evening. The psalmist speaks as if he wants Yahweh to be as pleased with him as he is with those who bring animals to sacrifice. He wants Yahweh to be pleased because the psalmist is praying or because of the words of his prayer. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: be like the evening sacrifice

contextId.occurrenceNote: Possible meanings are that the psalmist speaks as if a person correcting him were putting oil on his head 1) to honor him. Alternate translation: "when he corrects me, I will know that the one who corrects me is doing a good deed to me" or 2) to make his head feel better. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]] and [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-metaphor]])
contextId.glQuote: it will be like oil on my head

contextId.occurrenceNote: The writer compares humans to these thing to emphasize how short their lives are. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: like a breath ... like a passing shadow

contextId.occurrenceNote: These emphasize how easy it is for him to do these things. He covers the ground with snow as easily as a person covers something with a wool blanket. And, he removes the frost as easily as the wind blows ashes. (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He makes the snow like wool, he scatters the frost like ashes

contextId.occurrenceNote: Yahweh scatters hail as easily as a person would scatter bread crumbs. Alternate translation: "He dispenses the hail easily, as if it were crumbs" (See: [[rc://en/ta/man/translate/figs-simile]])
contextId.glQuote: He dispenses the hail like crumbs
